The fusion mechanism is postulated to be associated with the diffusion or desorption process of deuterium in Ti and Pd metals, where the deuterium might be intenscly compressed [1-3].

The X-ray diffraction measurements were performed after a series of measurements.

small: 1.6 u10 - em in 6 h. This means that the desorption rate of deuterium is very low compared with the absorptiom rale. X-ray difractiom measuremenl showed a formation of PdDa, after the experiments for the 25atm initial pressure condition. This deuterium concentration is consistent with that estimated from the resistivity (Fig. 3).

Pressure dependence of the deuterium concentration bchaviour on temperature suggests the strong influence of surface process in deuterium absorption. The deuterium absorption behaviour is dominated by three processes: the adsorption, the surface-passing. and the diffusion. Molecular orbital calculation of hydrogen binding on Pd clusters showed no barrier for the dissociation adsorption of hydrogen molecules. [ 6, 7 ],$ and a barrier of 10.6keal mol-' for passing the
r plane [8]. For the ditfusion process, the activation energy has been obtained experimentally to be about 4.8 kcalmol- bctwecn 70 and 300 K [9). The comparison of activation energies may support that the surface-passing process plays an important role in the deuterium absorption.
